This is my second Splotter game, following on from Indonesia. While Indonesia was plagued with a substandard manual and terrible quality parts (the components should at least be able to fit onto the spaces the game tells you to put them on!), Food Chain Magnate thankfully avoids that terribleness, mostly. Paper money still isn't wonderful, but the rest of the components were passable, and the artwork (save for the shared map) were fine to bordering on good.

However, this remains the only game where we genuinely couldn't finish the game - nobody wanted to, because after 3 hours we still hadn't really got to what people could describe as "fun" or "the game".

Like Indonesia, FCM has a lot of neat ideas and mechanisms, but they never really landed. The game has so many ways to make you fail early into a very long, near event length game, so the first few rounds are preprogrammed - every did the first opening move, then 2 did the same second move, the other 2 did the other second move. For your first, second, maybe even third game you won't know the consequences of why that's a bad move until its been made and then you've sunk 12 hours over three plays to realise "right, now I can have fun?"

Joris Wiersinga was quoted saying "We think that it is important that every single turn should matter. If you cannot lose the game on the first turn, then the first turn should not be played". And I think, ultimately, I agree. The first turn or five shouldn't have been played, because they were unfun, busy work where everything mattered and ultimately was boring.

I think ultimately, Splotter games aren't for me or my group.

Certain interesting mechanics and coherent aesthetics aside, pretty disappointing title. First two - three actions player takes set the flow of complete game and if trey won't play out as intended, player is left to suffer for next three hours participating in a completely unwinnable game which effectively makes the rest of it irrelevant. On top of that, somehow even being the one player that is currently winning is not fun or satisfactory at all.

Competitive aspect is pretty much illusory in a 3 or 4 player game as engaging into conflict over resources or customers with any other player grants free hand to others - there is nothing to win and you merely waste your moves to waste moves of another person. Milestones present complete lack of balance, ranging from mandatory in first few turns to even stand a chance, through useless, all the way to ones that might harm instead of reward players. I believe a lot of problems are supposedly fixed in add-on, but releasing a very expensive "DLC" that makes game playable (when base one is pretty pricey to begin with) is a scummy tactic and should not belong to the board game business.

I had 3 play-throughs with AWFUL super-unfun play experiences. I LOVE the Tech Tree idea in the game. But the numerous "I win on Turn 3" but we keep playing for 1.5 hours with no means to catch up is highly unfun (notably things like Radio tower lock-down, multi-variate resource lockouts, CFO runaway). The ability to wholly and completely cock-block your only source of development and progression in the game creates a highly un-fun play experience. If you haven't played daily an experienced play will not just crush you but create a unpleasant play experience. You really need to play 2-3 turns in advance. There are some game boards the clearly favor a particular strategy and if you don't see it you just lose. Period. Too many AUTO-WIN situations that don't end the game - you keep playing watching your game deteriorate turn after turn. I have been a tabletop play-tester for more than 10 years with my name in the back of many games, and I question whether this game went through ANY play-testing at all! Those two words "Auto-Win" as a play-tester always raises a red mental flag for me. Consider in Chess, there isn't an auto-win strategy (otherwise everyone would do that). It is one thing to "check" in the middle of a game, and another to "checkmate" on turn 3, and a wholly new class of poorly design game that "checkmates" on turn 3 but you keep playing for 2 more hours watching your soul get crushed. BGG needs a new category of game mechanic: lock-out-i've-already-won-on-turn-3-but-hey-let's-play-for-another-2-hours-mechanic. See most games that do have a "turbo-win" path, are smart enough to end the game then and there (q.v. Fluxx, Paris connection = all players bee-line to Marseilles). So I'm going to call that outstanding example of poor game design, a new mechanic called the "CRUSH YOUR SOUL" mechanic.

First off, the aesthetic. I get that it's going for a retro restaurant look, but it looks terrible. Cards are all coloured in block shades, the board looks like a print and play prototype, and there was very little actual art commissioned for this game at all. The game is also highly inelegant. There is a huge number of cards that take up even a decent sized table leaving little room for the tableau of employee cards that each player needs to build in front of them every round.

One of the main mechanisms in this game is that of the milestones. Basically if you're the first player to do a certain thing then you get a passive bonus for the rest of the game. Some of these are ridiculously powerful and would seem to preclude you from winning if you miss them (at least to me). The worst thing about these kind of mechanisms is that they require you to constantly monitor your opponents' progress to ascertain if they will beat you to a milestone. This is simply not interesting and becomes tiring.

Perhaps the worst aspect to this game is that simply nothing really happens in it (at least for some of the players). We played for about 2.5 hours, and the sum total of my business transactions (considering this is an economical game, which is won by making transactions) was the sale of 4 bottles of beer. Wow. Another player I think didn't manage to make a single transaction during the game. Unbelievable. The winner of our game was the first player to reach $100 (one of the aforementioned milestones) which meant he got a passive power that multiplies all his sales income by 1.5. This is amateur game design at it's best - a mechanism that literally makes the leading player uncatchable.

Game design that makes me angry:
- While it's an interesting twist to have players choose either a longer, medium or shorter game via hidden reserve cards, that's pointless because it's your first action in the game and can't be interacted later. You should not incorporate a Rock-Paper-Scissor mechanic in a long strategy game! You might guess the other players' reserve cards, but you have already had to commit to a certain build order. Some build orders can branch later, some can't. So you'd choose a build order that can branch, but there's one answer to every gamestate how you should branch so where's the game in that? It's more of a work situation, you shouldn't play by intuition. Game design that awards AP! Hurray!
- The game is NOT interactive, but a race! It's just that some BOs (build orders) require certain other players to do something first to work (which you can't plan for). The seemingly tactical gameplay is overshadowed by the power of 1x employees and milestones, which are way more gamedeciding than careful tile-placement and opponent interaction.
- The game is 100% open information. You can sit down and calculate your way to victory. You actually should. This makes it similar to chess, but without focus on tactical positioning, which is mostly irrelevant! What is the board for anyway? There's much added complexity without much gain.

This is a game like Chess and Go in the sense that a difference in skill determines the winner every time. The question then becomes: (1) is it worth investing the time and energy to master it and (2) can it be played with a group of friends of unequal skill level with everyone (including the less skilled players) enjoying the match? My personal answers to both of those questions are no. I already have a hard time when I win a game with friends where they did not enjoy the ride, I don't think I would be able to emotionally handle or enjoy winning a 3-4 hours game of this against less skilled players and/or lose a 3-4 hours game of this against more skilled players. I also believe that with repeated plays a series of preferred openings will be apparent (as in Chess), and knowing/memorizing those openings and sticking to them will be needed, limiting the illusion of individual freedom. Perhaps I am just too lazy to work when it's time to play, and this game requires work and gives little room for the kind of social interaction I enjoy: the auctions, bluffing, negotiating, social deduction, and opportunities for shock and laughter that I anjoy. There is probably 1/3rd of the game where you're focused on cards and getting started on the board, but determining what to do there falls out of a co-dependency with other players (as does when to have that switch in focus and balance). There is a certain amount of an engine building or a workforce management that you work on at the beginning and then there is this transition into board focused spatial play. In that regard, it sort of reminds me of a more complicated Lewis & Clark with staffing and card usage each turn with the spatial piece of The Great Zimbabwe added in and a slathering of generic euro engine building laid on top. One area that it different from TGZ is there seems to be a certain amount of runaway/snowball effect that the milestones provoke and the underlying question is "who can runaway faster" as the end post you're reaching for doesn't change, so delaying getting a milestone isn't to your benefit if you're going to try and incorporate it into your strategy. Conversely, because anyone who meets a milestone's condition that turn receives it, there is a dominant pathway of recruitment that provides for an advantage..

Compared to Indonesia (the other heavy econ Splotter I have), this feels more tactical, much more generic euro-y (build some semblance of an engine, crank it as hard as possible, try and run away with it, etc), less permanent (due to how marketing happens and things sort of turn quickly as a result of changed demands and a better ability to forecast what's coming) and less opaque in it's decision analysis. I would say it's less opaque as well in terms of just saying "well is this a good idea or no?" By no means is it a simple game, just a general comparison of the two titles (not all of that is bad, just different).

Conversely, the plethora of things you can do is almost dizzying in a wonderful way, even if there are two areas of strategic pivoting (once at the onset of the game, and again after about 6-8 turns when everyone is up and running for a bit). It is much more dynamic with price cutting/raising and changing demand via marketing expiration piece make for a really interesting twist on interaction, and I find it more interactive than either Indonesia (slightly) or Roads & Boats (definitely). Slightly stronger than Roads & Boats (primarily due to interaction style and play duration), not nearly as interesting to me as Indonesia (which I say is a 9). It rises above "generic heavy euro" but not by much.

I liked how the game is a combination of strategic choices (short game, medium game, long game) and tactical reactions (sniping milestones/garden houses, screwing up others' advertising, price wars), but in the end, it's still an engine-building euro in which there are "optimal paths" to victory.

The engines are the employees you hire and the milestones you achieve. The strategic paths are chosen before the start of the game and not known until midgame (hidden bank reserves), and changing your path in the first round as you see what others first hire is weighed down by the knowledge that you placed a bank reserve with a specific duration in mind.

I have no problem that poor moves are punished ruthlessly, nor that runaway leaders are possible when great plays or miscalculations happen. I have no problems with "the better player wins almost all the time" in games, either. But I don't like that much of the game feels "solved". There are certain milestones and openings and midgame maneuvers that are simply "better" based on the game state, and deviating from those is likely to just extend the game (unless you chose a long game, since you don't even contribute until Round 6).

On that note, I don't like that the "long game" option basically says "I won't even play the game until half of the milestones are gone, because I'm doing my own thing building a super engine over here, and I have no way to influence the board without killing my engine."

While this is currently rated a 7, I can only see it dropping with more plays as I explore the narrow pathways it offers and move on to other games.

*Edit* And it's dropped. There are optimal paths that can be charted out before the first turn, and you simply evaluate before your turn to see if they are still the optimal path, or if there's an opportunity/challenge that is better. Food Chain Magnate is almost unrivaled in the medium for the subtle intensity of its satire, even considering Splotter’s high standard for such things. This is a devilish, biting caricature of 1950’s Americana that is equal parts infatuation and disgust. The monochrome visual design, chauvinistic tokenization of the employees, absurd marketing tactics, and brainless, gluttonous behavior of the consumers all contribute to a repulsively amusing atmosphere that few if any games can match.

The jockeying for demand, supply, price, housing, and new restaurant locations on the shared board is mean-spirited and spatially compelling, and it is all expertly integrated with the personal employee tableaus. It's just a very cohesive, refined economic system borne out of a surprisingly light ruleset. But, unfortunately, it has a fatal flaw: lurking under this lovely foundation are the damned milestones, a subsystem that, to me, irreparably distorts what is an otherwise striking example of Splotter's timeless, focused, elegant design philosophy.

I understand their mechanical purpose is to provide a source of differentiation between the players in an otherwise no-luck, symmetric game, but the fastest path to some crucial early milestones is so obvious that they end up having the opposite effect: instead of creating interesting and dynamic asymmetries, they corral players into pre-planned, predictable, min-maxed lines of play (Train 1 Turn 2 or Hire 3 Turn 3) that completely overwhelm the strategic discourse of FCM.

That isn't to say that milestone-like effects don't work in principle. FCM's closest relative, The Great Zimbabwe, has similar first-come-first-served abilities in its Gods and Specialists, but they come at a static cost of VR, the dynamic cost of game-state information, and (critically) the benefits they provide are almost always exploitable by the other players because of TGZ's mutualistic economy. The significant and unilateral milestone benefits in FCM (that are gained for simply doing what you were going to do anyway) seem draconian by comparison. It isn't enough that someone is already losing because their opponents were just a little more efficient with their Recruiting Girls, this player now gets to lose even more because their opponents will be enjoying permanent (and exclusive) reductions in their salaries.

The whole subsystem is brutal to novices, and the jockeying it creates between experienced players isn't interesting or varied either. I'd like to believe that the randomized setup, initial restaurant placements, and emergent differences in players' employee tableaus could have been enough to drive the game without needing the milestones, but they're just too integrated into the system for me to seriously suggest omitting them.

A game with a fervent fanbase, and not without reason. FCM blends the strategic and the interactive in equally profound amounts. The rules aren't particularly difficult to learn for such a "heavy" game, but maneuvering within them surely is. As such, this will almost invariably reward the experienced player who can navigate the game's puzzle to eke the most out of it. For this reason, it has a problem with audience, because many will have to trudge through a lot of hopeless games to learn the strategy, only to find themselves trying to convince others to weather the same gauntlet in order to find people to play with.

If you can find equally invested players of similar skill, and who don't play slowly, you're set. Otherwise, the game can produce mixed experiences. I've had brilliant, exciting games and interminable slogs, and sometimes both feelings in the same session.

FCM has also produced the worst cases of analysis paralysis I've ever seen in board gaming. The highs the game can produce are really high, but the lows are potentially mind-numbing, including one session that I might rate as my worst single session...ever. I rate it a 6, but have never had a "6" session. It's more the average of the extremities this game produces.

Hard to recommend to a general audience, but if this is your type of game, it may rightly be among your favorites.

I find my rating dropping the more I play. We've been playing it a bit more recently, and I am reminded why this game falls a little short of the truly excellent euros that I usually play in terms of design.

The game has some real problems in its level of interaction and punishment along with its other design elements. In spite of how its advertised on the box and by some of its advocates, there are elements of luck in the game. Let's get this out of the way now: luck is based on randomness, and randomness is how we model the uncertain. Rock paper scissors, and, by extension, other similar simultaneous action mechanisms, have luck because you can never be 100% certain of your opponents selection. While the human brain is vastly more complex than a die, fundamentally, it is no different, in that however the decision within it is made, we are not privvy to knowing with 100% what that decision is. Whether or not your opponent has agency of this decision (which is actually an interesting subject matter in and of itself) is not relevant to whether or not it is random/involves luck. Therefore, the simultaneous play of restructuring in FCM (as well as the selection of reserve cards) involves some degree of luck.

The problem with this is that the game is also incredibly punishing for a wrong move. Frequently, as players become more skilled and/or closer in skill to one another, this luck has an outsized effect on the game. Players can get into frequent circumstances where, either in relation to number of open slots or pricing of their goods, the right play during restructuring is highly dependent on what other people are secretly choosing. That wouldn't be so bad, if it didn't also potentially scuttle your entire game by guessing wrong.

FCM also uses an action point system of sorts. During the 9-5 phase, you perform all of your employees actions. After having suffered through Vlaada's action point systems in Through the Ages and Mage Knight (Two games, which, while excellent in many ways, clearly suffer from these systems in terms of needless downtime), you would think designers would know that these systems can introduce ridiculous downtimes without any demonstrable increase in depth.

This game also has the issue of putting a lot of tedious arithmetic in between its players and the decisions they want to make. A lot of turns have an amount of arithmetic that takes some time to calculate but is perfectly possible if one spends several minutes figuring it out. This leads to awkward situations where one player is almost obligated to perform this arithmetic, because the punishment for just trying to use fuzzy estimation or winging it is losing the game. Meanwhile, this drags the game unnecessarily. One of the reasons point salad designs work is that it allows for more fuzzy calculation without being brutally punishing. I could also explain how this ties in with the other design issues I've mentioned earlier like the action point system, but I might save that for a more in-depth review.

The shame of this is that there's a lot of really interesting things going on in this game, and the mechanics are unique among the typical euros I often play. I really love the idea behind the balance of obtaining profits now vs. expanding your infrastructure and it makes for a really interesting balance. This is potential is why I still rate it fairly well. However, I think its design flaws are a good reinforcement for why heavy euros have often moved in the direction they have: more subtle interaction, single action turns, and point salad mechanics aren't just designs for people afraid of conflict - they have extremely beneficial upsides that overall improve the gameplay of people looking for more serious, analytical games.

I have dreams about playing this game. People who play this with me have dreams about playing this game. The org chart mechanic is SO GOOD. You have this puzzle-solving desire to plan way ahead, writing down the 27 steps you're going to take over the next 3 turns, only for an opponent to place a new restaurant or marketing campaign in a place you didn't consider. Now you need a new sheet of paper and another 30 minutes to figure out a completely different strategy.

The other major appeal to this is the fact that it's almost entirely open information and there is NO RANDOMNESS after setup. You are in complete control of having sold one lemonade for $10 the same turn someone else just sold 35 slices of pizza for $18 bucks a slice.

Its inevitable propensity for there to be a runaway leader actually doesn't hurt the game since it makes the game end the faster someone is winning. It's also very thematically appropriate. You didn't expect to get out-priced by having one-too-few Waitresses to break the demand tie, and suddenly instead of being able to fund your large class of employees that you just trained, you instead will have to let them all go. That's the restaurant business, baby!

The ridiculously overpowered milestones are also a crucial part of the game (also very thematic). Being the first to something gives you an incredibly big head-start, but it also forces you into a strategy you might not be comfortable with, depending on what your competitors are doing.
